H0.text: The integumentary and circulatory systems interact to produce antibodies that require essential amino acids.

H1.text: The digestive and reproductive systems are the two body systems that interact to produce antibodies requiring essential amino acids.

H2.text: Endocrine and respiratory systems are the two body systems that interact to produce antibodies that require essential amino acids.

H3.text: Digestive and immune systems interact to produce antibodies that require essential amino acids.

A4.text: In the stomach, gastric acid serves as a chemical defense against ingested pathogens.

A5.text: Antibodies are produced exclusively by B cells in response to antigens where initially, antibodies are formed as membrane-bound receptors, but upon activation by antigens and helper T cells, B cells differentiate to produce soluble antibodies.

A6.text: If one of the essential amino acids is not available in the required quantities, protein synthesis will be inhibited, irrespective of the availability of the other amino acids.

A7.text: Protein deficiency has been shown to affect all of the body's organs and many of its systems, for example affecting brain development in infants and young children; inhibiting upkeep of the immune system, increasing risk of infection; affecting gut mucosal function and permeability, thereby reducing absorption and increasing vulnerability to systemic disease; and impacting kidney function.
